Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN: Brain-Inspired Memristive Nanofiber Neural Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The human brain is currently the most powerful information processor known to man. Recent advances in neural networks and network science indicate that in order to match the power and efficiency of the brain, there is a need for a brand-new type of neuromorphic hardware that is able to connect physically independent neurons with dedicated, modifiable synapses. The PI and coworkers have developed a brain-inspired concept where, preliminary theoretical and experimental results show that a mat of memristive nanofibers is anticipated to yield neural networks with enhanced connectivity, functionality, and overall performance. This project aims at assessing the potential of this concept and it is guided by the overarching fundamental question can these brain-inspired memristive nanofiber neural network (MN3) architectures be effectively used for advanced neuromorphic computing.

The intellectual merit of the project stems from its goal to investigate the potential of MN3 architectures as the basis for novel neural network architectures that emulate the brain's computational abilities. This BRAIN project has three main objectives: 1) Manufacture MN3 architectures based on connective matrices of conductive-core, memristive-shell nanofibers and electrically characterize the networks in order to compare their characteristics to theoretical simulations; 2) Develop a simulation framework for modeling the proposed MN3 architectures in order to investigate and predict the signal behavior and computational properties of the networks; and 3) Investigate methods for implementing and training the networks as artificial neural networks, and evaluate the resulting networks on a set of benchmark machine learning tasks to determine performance characteristics.

The broader impacts of the project can be summarized in four main areas: a) investigation of a new brain-inspired design paradigm for fabricating neural networks that, if successful, can potentially transform the broad fields of neuromorphic hardware and machine learning; b) advancement of the discovery and understanding of neural network architectures while training undergraduate and graduate students in STEM fields; c) dissemination of the gained scientific and technological understanding of memristive networks through professional conferences, peer-review publications, and online hubs; and d) dissemination of tutorials and workshops on Artificial Intelligence targeting the general population in collaboration with the Cade Museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Under this project, we have been able to work and publish four papers in peer-reviewed journals. Here, we have shown that a random network with the MN3 architecture successfully carried out digit speech recognition tasks while simultaneously outperforming other alternative proposed architectures. Nonlinear behavior, separability and presence of a fading memory suggest that this architecture can be used to implement principles of reservoir computing. We have also demonstrated that in the MN3 architecture, the neuron density is higher by several orders of magnitude when compared to present state-of-the-art systems, with synaptic density reaching billion synapses per cm2. We have fabricated and characterized amorphous TiOx memristors fabricated via sol-gel method. The simplified method developed allows for a cheaper and efficient route to fabricate memristors. Despite a fragile active layer, the endurance of the device is comparable to other sol-gel based systems.

During the course of the project, the Nino Research Group has disseminated knowledge in several conferences held by institutions like Materials Research Society, International Conference on Neuromorphic Systems and Electrochemical Society. The research group was also invited to write a chapter in the upcoming Elsevier Science & Technology Book (Series-Korotcenkov) entitled "Metal Oxide Nanofibers and their Applications".  This project involved 13 undergraduate and 6 graduate students, many of them from underrepresented groups and minorities. The students have worked on several different aspects and have gained knowledge and skills in fabrication, electrical characterization of memristors and neural networks.

With our commitment towards making an impact beyond the university, we have completed three projects to promote education in the heart of Gainesville, a city affected by historically segregated neighborhoods, poor education systems, and high levels of poverty; a city often harmed by its central source of attention. Some involvement was based in UF due to the campus?s commitment to promoting service and outreach. For instance, we exhibited our work during UF's Engineering Week and spoke to middle and high school students interested in studying STEM. The group discussed two main areas of interest today -energy and water- and encouraged students to think about how they could improve the fields through research in materials science. Nonetheless, the group?s strongest collaboration was with the Cade Museum: a museum in Gainesville founded by Dr. Cade, a former UF professor of renal medicine and the inventor of Gatorade, and his family to create a center for creativity and invention.

A total of four MN3 core-shell devices were fabricated with differing designs to study their memristive behavior. The resistive switching properties were characterized by IV curves and pulse operation modes. Based on the forming process the core-shell nanowire can exhibit eightwise (Figure 1a) or counter eightwise (Figure 1b) bipolar resistive switching (BRS), and complementary resistive switching (CRS) (Figure 1c). The endurance and retention properties of bipolar switches was determined. The effect of compliance current during forming on the peak current during CRS operation was determined. Also, voltage pulse scheme to store information during CRS operation was performed. Additionally, current density-electric field analysis was performed to determine the conduction mechanism in high resistance state (HRS) and low resistance (LRS) during BRS mode of operation; and state 0 and state 1 of CRS mode of operation.

Additionally, to discover differences when analyzing brain functionality to differentiate healthy and diseased brains, we applied graph theory to the brain?s neural connectivity to explore the connectomes quantitative functionality. Here we apply this method on functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) of mice brain networks. These networks are based on 90 regions of interest (ROI's) found within the brain. Various quantifiers (degree, eigenvector centrality, betweenness centrality and collective influence) are applied to these networks to investigate their type of connectivity, effectiveness in transmitting information, and robustness. The networks display common areas of influence based on the quantifiers, with betweenness centrality containing the least similarity. These areas are commonly found on the left and bottom section of the circular network. These regions can then be related to their biological location within the brain. Figure 2 translates these influential ROI's between where the nodes are found in the circular network to where they are located within anatomical scans. By contrasting these relevant and influential areas between the two datasets, connectomics analysis can elucidate the mechanisms and development of Alzheimer's disease (AD). It was found that a type of node, considered a local node, is not as relevant within the connectivity of the diseased brains causing the change in dynamic of brain connectivity as a result of the disease.  This information is expected to be instrumental in the identification of biomarkers for the early diagnosis and treatment of AD.
